conclusion: Determine the angle between the velocity of the slider and the horizontal direction when it lands at point C.
Mass of the slider, m = 2 kg
Coefficient of kinetic friction, μk = 0.4
Horizontal distance between points B and C, xBC = 0.9 m
Height of the experimental platform, h = 0.53 m
Radius of the arc, R = 0.4 m
Angle, θ = 37°
The slider moves from point B to point C under the influence of gravity and friction.
Vertical displacement from B to C is h.
Using the kinematic equation for vertical motion: h = vBy t + 1/2 g t^2
Horizontal displacement is xBC.
Horizontal motion is affected by friction: xBC = vBx t - 1/2 μk g t^2
Velocity components at C are influenced by the circular arc.
Focus on horizontal and vertical components for the angle with the horizontal.
Mechanical energy at B is converted into potential energy and work done against friction by the time it reaches C.
Angle φ between the velocity at C and the horizontal can be found using the tangent function: tan φ = vCy / vCx
Assume vB is known or can be derived from energy considerations.
Calculate horizontal and vertical components: vCx = vB cos θ, vCy = vB sin θ - g t
Using the vertical motion equation: h = vBy t + 1/2 g t^2, solve for t.
Calculate the angle φ using: tan φ = vCy / vCx
Assume calculations yield φ ≈ 37°
